<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT5197</span> - Modelling for data analysis<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT5197">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Wray Buntine">Professor Wray Buntine</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5197&amp;tpCode=MO-TP1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Teaching Period 2</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5197&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5197&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT5197">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-monash-online.html">Monash Online</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Teaching Period 2 2019 (Online)</li><li>Teaching Period 5 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>(<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9133.html">FIT9133</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9131.html">FIT9131</a></span>) and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MAT9004.html">MAT9004</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>Monash Online offerings are only available to students enrolled in the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://online.monash.edu/course/graduate-diploma-data-science/?Access_Code=MON-GDDS-SEO2&amp;utm_source=seo2&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=MON-GDDS-SEO2">Graduate Diploma in Data Science</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Graduate Diploma in Data Science (<a href="http://online.monash.edu/course/graduate-diploma-data-science/?Access_Code=MON-GDDS-SEO2&amp;utm_source=seo2&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=MON-GDDS-SEO2">http://online.monash.edu/course/graduate-diploma-data-science/?Access_Code=MON-GDDS-SEO2&amp;utm_source=seo2&amp;utm_medium=referral&amp;utm_campaign=MON-GDDS-SEO2</a>)</span> via Monash Online.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit explores the statistical modelling foundations that underlie the analytic aspects of Data Science. Motivated by case studies and working through examples, this unit covers the mathematical and statistical basis with an emphasis on using the techniques in practice. It introduces data collection, sampling and quality. It considers analytic tasks such as statistical hypothesis testing and exploratory versus confirmatory analysis. It presents basic probability distributions, random number generation and simulation as well as estimation methods and effects such as maximum likelihood estimators, Monte Carlo estimators, Bayes theorem, bias versus variance and cross validation. Basic information theory and dependence models such as regression and log-linear models are also presented, as well as the role of general modelling such as inference and decision making, and predictive models.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>perform exploratory data analysis with descriptive statistics on given datasets;</li>
<li>construct models for inferential statistical analysis;</li>
<li>produce models for predictive statistical analysis;</li>
<li>perform fundamental random sampling, simulation and hypothesis testing for required scenarios;</li>
<li>implement a model for data analysis through programming and scripting;</li>
<li>interpret results for a variety of models.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Monash Online: In-semester assessment: 100%</p>
<p>On-campus: Examination (2 hours): 50%; In-semester assessment: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 144 hours per semester comprising:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>Contact hours for on-campus students:
<ul>
<li>Two hours/week lectures</li>
<li>Two hours/week laboratories</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Contact hours for Monash Online students:
<ul>
<li>Two hours/week online group sessions.</li>
<li>Online students generally do not attend lecture, tutorial and laboratory sessions, however should plan to spend equivalent time working through resources and participating in discussions.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Additional requirements (all students):
<ul>
<li>A minimum of 8 hours per week of personal study (22 hours per week for Monash online students) for completing lab/tutorial activities, assignments, private study and revision, and for online students, participating in discussions.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">RAD1031</span> - Radiologic biology 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-RAD1031">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-medical-imaging-and-radiation-sciences.html">Department of Medical Imaging and Radiation Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Imelda Williams">Mrs Imelda Williams</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Wendy MacLeod">Dr Wendy MacLeod</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=RAD1031&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-RAD1031">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Entry to the BRadMedImag.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD1021.html">RAD1021</a></span>; <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/RAD1061.html">RAD1061</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students will learn the principles of human biology and genetics, and the chemical, cellular and tissue organization of the human body. In addition, they will develop an understanding of the gross anatomical structure of the appendicular skeleton together with their radiographic appearances.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Connect how the biochemistry of molecules are integral in cellular functions</li>
<li>Describe the physiological processes of cells, in particular membrane transport and genetic inheritance and group cells into 4 tissue types</li>
<li>Relate anatomical terminology and osteology to the appendicular skeleton</li>
<li>Discuss the soft tissues and bony structures that comprise the upper limb and how these structures enable the upper limb to function</li>
<li>Discuss the soft tissues and bony structures that comprise the lower limb and how these structures enable the lower limb to function</li>
<li>Recognise and describe the radiographic appearances of the upper and lower limbs and apply this knowledge to radiographic positioning for the upper and lower limbs</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Laboratory portfolio requiring team work activities (25%)</li>
<li>Image Recognition test (1 hour) (15%)</li>
<li>Mid-semester Exam (1 hour) (15%)</li>
<li>Written exam (2 hours) (45%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle Requirement</p>
<ul>
<li>A pass in all elements of assessment is required. Students must obtain at least 50 % of the available marks for each element of assessment to pass the unit.</li>
<li>80% minimum attendance at practical and tutorial sessions</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle:</p>
<ul>
<li>Participation in anatomy practical</li>
<li>All elements of assessment must be passed to pass the unit.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/radiography-and-medical-imaging">Radiography and medical imaging</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/radiation-sciences">Radiation sciences</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT4042</span> - Industry-based learning<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">

<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT4042">

<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT4042">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>This unit is available to students enrolled in the Software Engineering specialisation of the Bachelor of Engineering (Honours) at Clayton campus who have been accepted into the industry-based learning placement program with at least 48 credit points of study accumulated for units offered by Faculty of Information Technology.</p>
<p>Prerequisite unit: <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT1008.html">FIT1008</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2085.html">FIT2085</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT4002.html">FIT4002</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students are on placement full time in a defined, graduate level role during a 22-week placement period at established partners of the Faculty of IT industry based learning program including major global companies, leading Australian companies and worldwide consultancies. The students on placement apply the knowledge, skills and practices of professional attitudes and behaviour developed in their academic units. They develop communication, time management, self-reflection and customer service skills in business situations, experience and participate professionally in the corporate environment and obtain feedback from experienced supervisors on their performance.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>set achievable and measurable goals;</li>
<li>identify useful theoretical knowledge that has been covered in prior coursework and knowledge that has not yet been covered;</li>
<li>develop and practice professional skills and attitudes including: initiative, communication, time-management and teamwork skills in a business environment;</li>
<li>develop solutions to business problems using information technology and other techniques;</li>
<li>prepare documentation and written reports of a professional standard;</li>
<li>address performance improvement opportunities identified by industry supervisors and self-assess opportunities for personal development;</li>
<li>develop information technology skills (such as business process modelling, performance enhancement of installed software, updating current software and developing new software) in a complex, corporate business environment;</li>
<li>apply engineering synthesis and design processes in a business and information technology environment;</li>
<li>evaluate and critique the engineering approaches undertaken during the conduct and management of the projects.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>In-semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Students on placement are deployed full-time for 22 weeks with the industry partners of the Faculty of IT industry-based learning program in a graduate level role within the company.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/software-engineering">Software engineering</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">ACW3021</span> - Performance measurement and control<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ACW3021">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-accounting.html">Department of Accounting</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Pak Mei Sen">Dr Pak Mei Sen</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Pak Mei Sen">Ms Pak Mei Sen</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ACW3021">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACW2020.html">ACW2020</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span> or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACB3021.html">ACB3021</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACC3200.html">ACC3200</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ACF3200.html">ACF3200</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Topics include the budget planning process including master budget preparation, budgeting standard costs and variance analysis, responsibility accounting, management by objectives and non-financial performance measurement, divisional performance, transfer pricing issues, program budgeting and other approaches, capital budgeting, strategic planning and control.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>apply traditional and contemporary performance measurement and control techniques to enable managers to measure and enhance organisational performance</li>
<li>analyse and make recommendations regarding the design of performance measurement and control systems</li>
<li>explain how behavioural implications are crucial for the effective design of performance measurement and control systems</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and/or group activities dealing with performance measurement and control and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACW3021.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 40% + Examination: 60%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGW3401</span> - Strategic management<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGW3401">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Erhan Atay">Dr Erhan Atay</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Erhan Atay">Dr Erhan Atay</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGW3401&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGW3401">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGW1010.html">MGW1010</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGC3110.html">MGC3110</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Business environments including markets, critical success factors, and strategies employed to gain a competitive advantage; the nature of strategic management; the analysis and interpretation of business environments; the nature of competition, relative position of firms, individual strategies and their relationship to critical success factors; strengths and weaknesses related to production, finance, research and development, marketing, administration; the role of structure, controls, rewards, culture and leadership in implementation.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify factors that help companies to survive and prosper</li>
<li>compare various business models and the actual processes of managing strategies</li>
<li>evaluate various techniques of analysing situations that require a strategic response</li>
<li>debate the factors that lead to strategy success and failure</li>
<li>apply strategic management concepts in particular cases.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Examination: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">PBH2002</span> - Foundations of biostatistics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-PBH2002">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-public-health-and-preventive-medicine.html">School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Baki Billah">Dr Baki Billah</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nassif Hossain">Nassif Hossain</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=PBH2002&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-PBH2002">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in an Undergraduate Degree</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>HSC2141</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit introduces students to the basic principles and methods used in biostatistics as applied to public health and clinical research.</p>
<p>The key concepts covered include the technical qualifications necessary for analysing and interpreting data on a descriptive and bivariate level.</p>
<p>The unit will cover topics which include classification of health data, sampling methods;, study design, summarizing data using simple statistical methods and graphical presentation, sampling distributions, quantifying uncertainty in results from a sample, statistical distributions (normal and t-distribution),  comparing two independent/paired groups using t-test (p-value) and confidence intervals, comparing more than two groups using Analysis of variance (ANOVA), non-parametric tests for comparing two or more groups when normality assumptions do not hold, assessing the association between an outcome and an exposure using the chi-squared test, and risk comparisons (RR &amp; OR).</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Examine and explain the importance of biostatistics in public health studies</li>
<li>Classify data into appropriate measurement types.</li>
<li>Present data using relevant tables, graphical displays, and summary statistics.</li>
<li>Formulate and evaluate research hypotheses into a statistical context in public health studies.</li>
<li>Accurately interpret statistical methods and results reported in health publications.</li>
<li>Analyse data using the SPSS software package.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Written report (1500 words, excluding data analysis output and tables) (25%)</li>
<li>Data analysis report (1800 words, excluding data analysis output and tables) (30%)</li>
<li>Online quiz (MCQ) (30 minutes) (10%)</li>
<li>Examination (MCQ/SAQ) (2 hours) (35%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle Requirement: 80% attendance at tutorials and participation in online tasks.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>1 hour lecture, 2 hour tutorial, 3 hours of directed online student learning activities, plus 6 hours of self-directed study per week.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/health-science">Health science</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/public-health">Public health</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">ARC1102</span> - Technologies and environments 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ARC1102">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-architecture.html">Department of Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Maryam Gusheh">Associate Professor Maryam Gusheh</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Maryam Gusheh">Associate Professor Maryam Gusheh</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ARC1102&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ARC1102">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ARC1001.html">ARC1001</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/OHS1000.html">OHS1000</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ARC1002.html">ARC1002</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Delivered in conjunction with <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ARC1002.html">ARC1002</a></span>. Explores materials, component systems, products and fabrication systems as they apply to building construction. This includes the study of materials in terms of their physical and chemical properties, environmental sustainability and impact, and involves physical testing and assessment of materials and their application in architecture.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand the basic use and properties of materials and fabrication techniques as they apply to architectural design;</li>
<li>Be familiar with historic and contemporary development of construction materials, component systems and fabrication techniques;</li>
<li>Understand basic physical and structural principles as they pertain to different materials;</li>
<li>Understand issues of environmental sustainability in relation to materials selection and design;</li>
<li>Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit of study.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 4 contact hours plus 8 hours of independent study.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

</li>
<li class="breadcrumbs__item">
<a class="breadcrumbs__link" href="https://www.monash.edu/study">Study</a>
<span aria-hidden="true" class="breadcrumbs__divider">|</span>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT3152</span> - Data analytics<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT3152">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=John Betts">Dr John Betts</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT3152&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT3152">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>One of <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT1006.html">FIT1006</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ETC1000.html">ETC1000</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ETF1100.html">ETF1100</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT2086.html">FIT2086</a></span> or equivalent. (For example BUS1100, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ETC1010.html">ETC1010</a></span>, ETC2010, ETF2211, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ETW1000.html">ETW1000</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ETW1010.html">ETW1010</a></span>, ETW1102, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ETW2111.html">ETW2111</a></span>, ETX1100, ETX2111, ETX2121, MAT1097, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/STA1010.html">STA1010</a></span>)</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ETX2250.html">ETX2250</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>In recent years the world has seen an explosion in the quantity and variety of data routinely recorded and analyzed by research and industry, prompting some social commentators to refer to this phenomenon as the rise of "big data," and the analysts and practitioners who investigate the data as "data scientists."</p>
<p>The data may come from a variety of sources, including scientific experiments and measurements, or may be recorded from human interactions such as browsing data or social networks on the Internet, mobile phone usage or financial transactions. Many companies too, are realising the value of their data for analysing customer behavior and preferences, recognising patterns of behaviour such as credit card usage or insurance claims to detect fraud, as well as more accurately evaluating risk and increasing profit.</p>
<p>In order to obtain insights from big data new analytical techniques are required by practitioners. These include computationally intensive and interactive approaches such as visualisation, clustering and data mining. The management and processing of large data sets requires the development of enhanced computational resources and new algorithms to work across distributed computers.</p>
<p>This unit will introduce students to the analysis and management of big data using current techniques and open source and proprietary software tools. Data and case studies will be drawn from diverse sources including health and informatics, life sciences, web traffic and social networking, business data including transactions, customer traffic, scientific research and experimental data. The general principles of analysis, investigation and reporting will be covered. Students will be encouraged to critically reflect on the data analysis process within their own domain of interest.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>demonstrate the ability to transform real world problems into ones that can then be solved using data analytics techniques;</li>
<li>cleanse and prepare data for analysis;</li>
<li>analyse large data sets using a range of statistical, graphical and machine-learning techniques;</li>
<li>validate and critically assess the results of analysis;</li>
<li>interpret the results of analysis and communicate these to a broad audience.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 60%; In-semester assessment: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week comprising:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="a">
<li>Contact hours for on-campus students:

<ul>
<li>Two hours of lectures</li>
<li>One 2-hour laboratory</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Additional requirements (all students):

<ul>
<li>A minimum of 8 hours independent study per week for completing lab and project work, private study and revision.</li>
</ul></li>
</ol><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/advanced-computer-science">Advanced computer science</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/business-information-systems">Business information systems</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/computational-science">Computational science</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/data-science">Data science</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/it-for-business">IT for business</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">CIV6882</span> - Flood hydraulics and hydrology<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">0 points, SCA Band 2, 0.000 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CIV6882">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-civil-engineering.html">Department of Civil Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeff Walker">Professor Jeff Walker</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Valentijn Pauwels">Assoc Professor Valentijn Pauwels</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CIV6882&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CIV6882">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>This unit is available only to Engineering PhD students.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit focuses on flood modelling for engineering design. Methods to estimate design flood magnitudes from experimental observations will be presented. Hydrologic and hydraulic routing models will be introduced along with software packages that apply these models.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>run operational hydrologic models.</li>
<li>parameterize models.</li>
<li>undertake flood frequency analysis.</li>
<li>analyse digital terrain models and outlines catchments.</li>
<li>understand hydraulics and apply hydraulic models.</li>
<li>understand runoff routing and apply operational routing models.</li>
<li>understand and apply state updating techniques.</li>
<li>work both independently and collaboratively on flood management problems.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous assessment: 40%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 60%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>On-campus - 3 hours lectures/practice and 9 hours of private study per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Civil Engineering</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">BFS5959</span> - Accounting and finance for international managers<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-BFS5959">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-banking-and-finance.html">Department of Banking and Finance</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Stefani Coetzee">Ms Stefani Coetzee</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=G Els">Prof G Els</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFS5959&amp;tpCode=T2-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 2</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BFS5959&amp;tpCode=T4-57&amp;tpYear=2019">Term 4</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BFS5959">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Term 2 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li><li>Term 4 2019 (On-campus block of classes)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BFM5959.html">BFM5959</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BFZ5959.html">BFZ5959</a><span class="unitoffered">Not offered in 2019</span></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit provides an introduction to terminology, concepts and techniques used in accounting and finance. Important areas to be discussed include understanding financial statements, basic analysis of financial statements, working capital management, the framework of capital budgeting, and time value of money. International issues in accounting will also be examined. The emphasis will be on decision making and value creation in a global environment.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>develop an understanding of the nature and roles of accounting and finance in managing in a global environment</li>
<li>explore the process of value management in a global world</li>
<li>develop competencies and computational skills required to prepare and evaluate the strategies and tactics associated with value creation</li>
<li>develop an appreciation for the relevance of theory and its linkage with practice</li>
<li>apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and/or group activities dealing with principles of accounting and finance and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered in BFS5959.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">MED2200</span> - Principles of medicine 2<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">24 points, SCA Band 3, 0.500 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MED2200">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Peter Barton">Associate Professor Peter Barton</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Parasakthi Navaratnam">Professor Parasakthi Navaratnam</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Richard Loiacono">Dr Richard Loiacono</a>
        
        (Clayton)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Amudha Kadirvelu">A. Prof Amudha Kadirvelu</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MED2200&amp;tpCode=FY-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Full year</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MED2200">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Full year 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Full year 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED1100.html">MED1100</a></span> and <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED1200.html">MED1200</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MED2100.html">MED2100</a></span></p>
<p>Must be enrolled in course version 4533 or M6011</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit  further consolidates and extends knowledge, and skills in medicine.</p>
<p>Content encompasses the four themes of the Bachelor of Medical Science and Doctor of Medicine (MD) curriculum: Theme I (Personal and Professional Development), Theme II (Society, Population, Health and Illness), Theme III (Scientific Basis of Clinical Practice) and Theme IV (Clinical Skills).</p>
<p>Learning approaches support students in integrating knowledge and skills relevant to common and significant illnesses and conditions from a systems based perspective.  Students are expected to integrate and apply learning relevant to patient care and the practice of medicine.</p>
<p>This unit provides the foundation for learning in clinical settings in later years of the course.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Theme I - Personal and Professional Development</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Use key ethical and legal principles to discuss issues pertinent to health care and clinical contexts.

<p>Theme II - Society, Population, Health and Illness</p></li>
<li>Examine key social, economic and environmental determinants of health on status and outcomes in marginalised groups, including the Indigenous population.</li>
<li>Explain concepts in prevention science and approaches used in health promotion.</li>
<li>Explain concepts in population health, epidemiology and measurement of health and disease in populations.</li>
<li>Describe the role of health care services in maintaining health and in monitoring, managing and preventing disease.</li>
<li>Using prescribed methodologies search for and critique information from medical research literature and popular information sources.

<p>Theme III - Scientific Basis of Clinical Practice</p></li>
<li>Describe the structure and function of the human body at cellular, organ, system and whole body levels.</li>
<li>Explain biological, psychological and social factors pertinent to understanding human development, health, illness and behaviour.</li>
<li>Describe common and important illnesses, conditions and disorders</li>
<li>Explain fundamental pathological processes and causes underlying specified illnesses and conditions.</li>
<li>Describe drug classes and identify the use and actions of drugs in these groups.

<p>Theme IV - Clinical Skills</p></li>
<li>Elicit and summarise a structured, comprehensive and logical history in simulated environments.</li>
<li>Perform and summarise an appropriate examination for specified systems in simulated environments.</li>
<li>Propose and  justify the reasoning for a differential diagnosis (list) at a basic level for specified systems.</li>
<li>Competently perform specified clinical procedures and tasks in simulated environments.</li>
<li>Identify relevant investigations for specified problems or conditions.</li>
<li>Outline a basic management plan for specified common problems and conditions.</li>
<li>Use principles for effectively communicating medical information to patients in simulated settings.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Comprehensive integrated puzzle (2 hours) (5%)</li>
<li>OSCE assessment (8 stations, 10 minutes each) (30% total) (hurdle)</li>
<li>2 x Mid-year examination (2 + 3 hours) (25%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>2 x End of year examination (2 + 3 hours) (25%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Vertically Integrated Assessment (VIA) written examination (3 hours) (15%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle requirements:</p>
<p>Students must attend a minimum of 80% of designated teaching activities to pass this unit.</p>
<p>Students must complete all requisite on-line modules</p>
<p>Students must pass the OSCE assessment and must pass the combined written examinations to pass this unit.</p>
<p>The Borderline Group method is used to determine the pass score and borderline range for the OSCE, and the Angoff method is used to determine the pass score and borderline range for the combined written examinations</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Note: This is a 24 credit point unit delivered across a full year which equates to a 12 credit point workload per semester.</p>
<p>In each semester students will be provided with 14 hours of teacher directed study per week including lectures (6 hours) active learning integrated workshops (2 x 2 hours) each week plus 10 hours of on-line and self-directed study.</p>
<p>Total per week = 24 hours</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/medicine-and-surgery">Medicine and Surgery</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3130</span> - Arts international internship<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 1, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3130">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>

<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3130">

</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Students who have attained a distinction average and who have completed 96 points of study with a minimum of 48 points in Arts</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>The unit may be counted towards any major as an elective where approved by the faculty.</li>
<li>This is an <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/internships/">internship</a><span class="hbk-print-url">internship (<a href="http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/internships/">http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/internships/</a>)</span> unit that requires an application to be enrolled.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered as part of the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">Summer Arts Program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Summer Arts Program (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html">http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/summer-program.html</a>)</span>.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered as part of the <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/winter-program.html">Winter Arts Program</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Winter Arts Program (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/winter-program.html">http://www.monash.edu/students/courses/arts/winter-program.html</a>)</span>.</li>
<li>The unit may be offered in <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">non-standard teaching periods</a><span class="hbk-print-url">non-standard teaching periods (<a href="http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census">http://www.monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census</a>)</span>.</li>
<li>This is an <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/pubs/2019handbooks/aos/arts-enrichment-units/index.html">Arts enrichment unit</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Arts enrichment unit (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/pubs/2019handbooks/aos/arts-enrichment-units/index.html">https://www.monash.edu/pubs/2019handbooks/aos/arts-enrichment-units/index.html</a>)</span>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students are placed as interns with a host partner organisation and complete either a unique research project or work experience-based project jointly defined by the host partner organisation and the unit coordinator. The host partner organisations are from a diverse range of industries and sectors, including government departments, private industry and not-for-profit organisations. Students communicate the research or work experience in a final project in the format specified by the host partner organization and unit coordinator, such as a research report, consultation paper, manual or submission. The host partner organisation provides field supervision and the faculty provides academic supervision. The main component of the unit involves students undertaking a minimum of 144 hours equivalent of placement in order to complete a final project agreed upon between the host partner organisation and the faculty. The host partner organisation will appoint a field supervisor for the project although the chief examiner remains the principal assessor for the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Apply broad discipline knowledge to design a proposal for a final project relating to an internship;</li>
<li>Exercise critical thinking and professional judgement by developing a plan for a final project relating to an internship;</li>
<li>Demonstrate critical reflective practice skills as a result of completing an internship;</li>
<li>Demonstrate advanced communication skills by reporting on an aspect of the work undertaken for an internship;</li>
<li>Execute a final project with a degree of independence and accountability relating to an internship.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 288 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>This unit requires a minimum of 144 hours equivalent of placement with a host partner organisation. Prior to undertaking the internship, students must attend an on-campus 2-hour seminar. It is anticipated that the remaining hours to complete a total of 288 hours will be spent on relevant readings, reflection and maintenance of assessment.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html">Bachelor of Global Studies</a><span class="hbk-print-url">Bachelor of Global Studies (<a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html">http://www.monash.edu.au/pubs/2018handbooks/courses/A2001.html</a>)</span></p>
<p><a href="../aos/holocaust-and-genocide-studies">Holocaust and genocide studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/italian-studies">Italian studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/arts-enrichment-units">Arts enrichment units</a></p>
</div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3926</span> - Gongs, punks and shadow plays<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3926">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-sir-zelman-cowen-school-of-music.html">Sir Zelman Cowen School of Music</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Adrian McNeil">Dr Adrian McNeil</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Adrian McNeil">Dr Adrian McNeil</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3926">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS2926</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit explores the diverse musical practices of Southeast Asia, while investigating regional commonalities and variations concerning the predominance of gongs and bamboo instruments, spirit practices, dance forms, shadow puppetry, colonial influences and popular musics. By examining the geopolitical impact of hills, forests, plains and coasts, the unit also addresses the interplay of tradition and modernity; the impact of war, migration and diaspora on expressive cultures; the relationship between performance practice and musical meaning; and, the role of music in the construction of ethnic, regional and national identities. In addition, students participate in a gamelan ensemble (an Indonesian percussion orchestra) as part of the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completion of the unit, students are able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Articulate how selected theoretical perspectives are applicable to the study of Southeast Asian musical practices;</li>
<li>Demonstrate critical reflective practice skills through the keeping of a learning journal and the writing of a summative learning report;</li>
<li>Distinguish between selected musical practices of dominant lowland and marginalised upland peoples, as well as 'traditional' and 'popular' musics of Southeast Asia.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/composition-and-music-technology">Composition and music technology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/ethnomusicology-and-musicology">Ethnomusicology and musicology</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/indonesian-studies">Indonesian studies</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/music">Music</a></p>
<p><a href="../aos/music-performance">Music performance</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3781</span> - English as an international language: Writing across cultures<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3781">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-english-as-an-international-language.html">English as an International Language</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Atefeh Hadi">Dr Atefeh Hadi</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nina Fang">Miss Nina Fang</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS3781&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3781">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>With English being an international language, using only one pattern of writing in English as the 'best' model because English speaking countries are the 'exclusive sole owners' of the language may no longer be relevant. What is considered to be "good or bad writing" in English, therefore, deserves thorough and critical investigation. This unit encourages students to investigate a variety of English writing practices in intercultural communication contexts. It enables students to challenge the assumption behind 'standard' and 'conventional' writing practices in English, as well as to discuss key aspects and features of writing in English for international communication.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon completion of the unit it is expected that students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>explain how a person brings his/her own cultural practices and identities into writing in English;</li>
<li>develop awareness of features of writing in World Englishes across cultures;</li>
<li>develop a critical perspective on 'good writing' in today's globalised world;</li>
<li>challenge the assumptions behind one hegemonic model of writing in English for international communication;</li>
<li>develop meta-cultural writing competence for successful written intercultural communication.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/linguistics">Linguistics</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">SWK4001</span> - Honours research methods<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-SWK4001">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-social-work.html">Department of Social Work</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Catherine Flynn">Dr Catherine Flynn</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Catherine Flynn">Dr Catherine Flynn</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-SWK4001">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>3rd year Social Work units (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK3180.html">SWK3180</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK3220.html">SWK3220</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK3230.html">SWK3230</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK3400.html">SWK3400</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK3410.html">SWK3410</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/SWK3440.html">SWK3440</a></span>).</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in BSW(Hons), BA/BSW(Hons) or BHSc/BSW(Hons).</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The honours research methods unit introduces students to the theoretical methodological and ethical issues that underpin social work research. It provides direction and guidance to honours students in identifying a meaningful research question and develops the skills and knowledge students need to develop a research proposal. It re-introduces students to quantitative and qualitative research frameworks and data analysis techniques they need to both undertake their study and write a research report.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify a research topic that addresses a significant social work issue.</li>
<li>Utilise acquired knowledge of the research process to develop an honours project proposal.</li>
<li>Critically review literature in their research area.</li>
<li>Formulate a researchable question.</li>
<li>Review research frameworks to inform methodological choices.</li>
<li>Present an informed discussion of the ethical issues involved in their research project, including the completion of an ethics application as appropriate.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Completion of the research proposal - literature review and methodology (4,500 words) and submission of relevant ethics application (100%)</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>OCDL students are required to attend at least one on campus workshop.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/health-science">Health science</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Additional information on this unit is available from the faculty at:</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="http://www.med.monash.edu.au/socialwork/">http://www.med.monash.edu.au/socialwork/</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">RSE4111</span> - Numerical modelling<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-RSE4111">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-civil-engineering.html">Department of Civil Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jeff Walker">Professor Jeff Walker</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Stephan Arndt">Associate Professor Stephan Arndt</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-RSE4111">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CIV2242.html">CIV2242</a></span> and completion of 132 credit points</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students are introduced to the state-of-the-art in numerical methods and their application for engineering design. The unit provides an overview of existing numerical methods and theory and provides a background for the selection of the most appropriate numerical modelling procedure for specific applications.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>At the successful completion of this unit you will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Appraise the current state-of-the-art numerical methods and their theory.</li>
<li>Assess how numerical schemes and grids influence the behavior of the model.</li>
<li>Assess the various sources of error that may turn up in the model.</li>
<li>Appraise the limitations of a model.</li>
<li>Demonstrate how numerical models can be as a tool to solve problems in rock engineering.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Continuous Assessment: 50%</p>
<p>Examination (2 hours): 50%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>2 hours lectures, 3 hours practice class and 7 hours private study per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Geological Engineering</p>
<p>Mining Engineering</p>
<p>Oil and Gas Engineering</p>
<p>Renewable Energy Engineering</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
